Description: Isis seated on high-backed throne. The throne has beaded detail along the top, a square feature in each corner of the back, and elaborate front legs. The goddess wears her Isis-shawl, knotted and with fringed edges, the left breast exposed; she holds the child Horus with her left hand, and he grips her right hand with his left. She has a horned and feathered crown with a disc and ears of wheat; Harpokrates wears a Double Crown. Slightly curved plain-faced plinth. Back plain; vent in a slight circular depression. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt. back.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in the Fayum. Roman, first to second century ad.
